chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text: In this problem, we will solve problems relating to the concept of earnings per share based on the earnings before interest and tax.

Earnings per share is a measure of how much a company earns per outstanding share. This can be solved by dividing the difference between the earnings and dividends by the number of outstanding shares.

**a.)** In this problem, we will assume that the earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) is equal to $\$79,000$.

For this, we will first solve for the interest per plan. To do this, we will multiply. the given rate by the debt for that specific plan. 

For Plan I:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Interest}&=\$109,250 \times 0.10\\[15 pt]
&=\$10,925
\end{aligned}$$

For Plan II:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Interest}&=\$247,000 \times 0.10\\[15 pt]
&=\$24,700
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the interest for Plan I and Plan II are $\$10,925$ and $\$24,700$, respectively.

Now that we have the interest, we will subtract this from the EBIT of each plan. 

For Plan I:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{New earnings}&=\$79,000-\$10,925\\[15 pt]
&=\$68,075
\end{aligned}$$

For Plan II:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{New earnings}&=\$79,000-\$24,700\\[15 pt]
&=\$54,300
\end{aligned}$$

The new earnings for Plan I and Plan II are $\$68,075$ and $\$54,300$, respectively.

From these new earnings, we can now solve for the earnings per share (EPS) by dividing the new earnings by the number of outstanding shares.

For Plan I:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EPS}&=\dfrac{\$68,075}{12,700}\\[15 pt]
&=\$5.36
\end{aligned}$$

For Plan II:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EPS}&=\dfrac{\$54,300}{9,800}\\[15 pt]
&=\$5.54
\end{aligned}$$

For the all-equity plan:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EPS}&=\dfrac{\$79,000}{15,000}\\[15 pt]
&=\$5.27
\end{aligned}$$

Based on this, Plan I has the highest earnings per share (EPS) among the three plans presented.

Isolate the unknown on one side:

$$\begin{aligned}
15,000\text{EBIT}-12,700\text{EBIT}&=\$163,875,000\\[15 pt]
\dfrac{2,300\text{EBIT}}{2,300}&=\dfrac{\$163,875,000}{2,300}\\[15 pt]
\text{EBIT}&=\$71,250
\end{aligned}$$

The break-even EBIT for Plan I is $\$71,250$

Isolate the unknown on one side:

$$\begin{aligned}
15,000\text{EBIT}-9,800\text{EBIT}&=\$370,500,000\\[15 pt]
\dfrac{5,200\text{EBIT}}{5,200}&=\dfrac{\$370,500,000}{5,200}\\[15 pt]
\text{EBIT}&=\$71,250
\end{aligned}$$

The break-even EBIT for Plan II is $\$71,250$
As we can see, the break-even EBIT for both plans is the same because of the M&M theory that states that the present value of the future cash flow of the company is not affected by capital structure.

Cross multiply then isolate the variables:

$$\begin{aligned}
9,800\text{EBIT}-\$107,065,000&=12,700\text{EBIT}-\$313,690,000\\[15 pt]
12,700\text{EBIT}-9,800\text{EBIT}&=\$313,690,000-\$107,065,000\\[15 pt]
2,900\text{EBIT}&=\$206,625,000
\end{aligned}$$

Divide both sides by $2,900$:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EBIT}&=\dfrac{\$206,625,000}{2,900}\\[15 pt]
&=\$71,250
\end{aligned}$$

As we can see, the EBIT for this is still the same as what was computed in part b. This is still due to the M&M Theory where the present value of future cash flows is not affected by capital structure.

Cross-multiply then isolate the like terms:

$$\begin{aligned}
11,850\text{EBIT}-\$129,461,250&=10,033\text{EBIT}\\[15 pt]
1,817\text{EBIT}&=\$129,461,250
\end{aligned}$$

Divide both sides by $1,817$:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EBIT}&=\dfrac{\$129,461,250}{1,817}\\[15 pt]
&=\$71,250
\end{aligned}$$

The break-even EBIT for this is $\$71,250$

Cross-multiply then isolate the like terms:

$$\begin{aligned}
11,850\text{EBIT}-\$292,695,000&=7,742\text{EBIT}\\[15 pt]
4,108\text{EBIT}&=\$292,695,000
\end{aligned}$$

Divide both sides by $4,108$:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EBIT}&=\dfrac{\$292,695,000}{4,108}\\[15 pt]
&=\$71,250
\end{aligned}$$

The break-even EBIT for this is $\$71,250$
As we can see, the break-even EBIT is the same for all due to the M&M theory that the capital structure does not affect the present value of future cash flows.
